<a href="style=%22border-bottom:none!important;%22" target="_blank"></a>
</th>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good Wednesday morning. </strong>Today is the 20th anniversary of the PlayStation 2’s release in Japan, so we asked around the office for some memories and...console-ation:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Jenny Rothenberg, director of growth: </strong></span><span>“Crash Bandicoot. Warrrrrped.”</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Tyler Denk, senior product lead: </strong></span><span>"</span><span><span>Spending hours building your own skate park in Tony Hawk." </span></span><span>
</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Michael Ferrante, director of integrated marketing: </strong></span><span><span>“Not so much a memory, but rather a vast gap where my ninth grade should have been.”</span></span><span>
</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Ryan Duffy, Emerging Tech Brew writer: </strong></span><span><span>“Fondest memory is telling my PS2 friends that Xbox is better.”</span></span><span>
</span>
</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/03/fed-cuts-interest-rates-stem-effects-coronavirus?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Extraordinary Times Call for Monetary Policy Measures
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Jerome Powell testifying before Congress" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC84MC9qZXJvbWVfcG93ZWxsLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>U.S. Federal Reserve</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When the U.S. economy gets a mustard stain, you can always rely on the Federal Reserve for Tide to Go. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a surprising move yesterday, the central bank <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/03/fed-cuts-rates-by-half-a-percentage-point-to-combat-coronavirus-slowdown.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">cut interest rates</a> by half a percentage point, the first time it’s applied Emergen-C stimulus since the 2008 financial crisis. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“The fundamentals of the U.S. economy remain strong,” a Fed statement read. "However, the coronavirus poses evolving risks to the economy.” </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Fed Chair Jerome Powell acknowledged that the rate cut won’t reduce the infection rate or repair broken supply chains, but it will “help boost household and business confidence.” </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The reaction</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Markets: </strong>not reassured. The major indexes each fell nearly 3%, wiping out any optimism from Monday’s rally. Investors loaded up on the canned beans of the finance world—government bonds—dropping the 10-year Treasury yield below 1% for the first time ever.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">President Trump:</strong> not satisfied with the amount of easing and cutting. “More easing and cutting!” he tweeted following the central bank’s announcement. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Treasury Secretary Mnuchin: </strong>picked up his cheerleader pom poms. “They did the right thing getting ahead of this...I applaud the Fed on this move.” </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">But this is a global problem</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And major economies <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/03/business/central-banks-coronavirus-g7.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">don’t seem united</a> in their response. Before the Fed’s decision yesterday, leaders from the G7 said they were “closely monitoring the spread of the coronavirus disease,” but didn’t lay out any coordinated action. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>As we discussed yesterday, </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/02/quick-debrief-central-bank-meetings?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">interest rates</a></span><span> are already at historic lows across the world, leaving central banks without First Aid kits to dress economic wounds.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Bank of England, for example, is in no hurry to cut rates. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>in the U.S., more cuts seem imminent. The next one could happen at the Fed's regularly scheduled meeting March 17–18. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F03%2F03%2Ffed-cuts-interest-rates-stem-effects-coronavirus" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/03/companies-governments-try-root-coronavirus-profiteers?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Profiteer No Profiteering
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="A shelf with no supplies left " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC84MS9lbXB0eV9zaGVsdmVzLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Justin Sullivan/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As the coronavirus spreads, companies and governments are struggling to keep opportunists from <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/03/amazon-walmart-e-retailers-battle-price-gouging-on-coronavirus-products.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">exploiting demand</a> for medical supplies. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>As of yesterday, there were more than 91,300 confirmed cases and at least 3,110 deaths worldwide. In the U.S., there have been at least nine deaths and over 100 confirmed cases. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Fear of contracting the virus sent prices of supplies like facemasks and hand sanitizer, especially those hawked by third-party sellers, through several roofs. Amazon said last week it had taken down over 1 million listings because of price gouging or misleading descriptions related to the coronavirus. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>But that's not enough. The FT found a pack of 20 masks that usually goes for around $15 being </span><span><a href="https://www.ft.com/content/8db033ac-5d11-11ea-b0ab-339c2307bcd4?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">resold on the site for $387</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>a New York state senator floated a bill to step up penalties on businesses that raise prices on medical supplies by more than 10% during public health emergencies. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GEOGRAPHY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/03/coastal-cities-capture-higher-share-tech-growth?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Don’t Share a Pizza With San Diego
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Two recent analyses suggest a few U.S. cities are hogging the fruits of the U.S.’ record economic expansion. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The first:</strong> The WSJ reports that the proportion of U.S. cities expecting general fund revenue to slide more than 3% by the end of fiscal 2019 <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/for-growing-numbers-of-struggling-u-s-cities-the-downturn-has-arrived-11583248603?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">jumped to 27% from 17%</a> (adjusting for inflation, of course). </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>General fund revenue = city money not yet designated for a specific purpose. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>When cities are budget-strapped, not only do services suffer and taxes go up, but officials can’t plan long-term. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Some U.S. cities are flush with cash provided by new, highly taxable tech workers. But a larger share still suffer from the extended bottoming out of American manufacturing. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Which brings us to <a href="https://www.brookings.edu/research/tech-is-still-concentrating/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=newsletter_axioslogin&stream=top&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">the second analysis</a>, courtesy of The Brookings Institution. The think tank’s thinkers say tech employment growth is heavily concentrating in coastal cities like Seattle, Boston, San Francisco, and San Diego. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The top 10 metro areas with the highest shares of the U.S. digital services industry captured 47.9% of the country’s new tech jobs from 2010 to 2018.</span></li>
</ul>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FOOD & BEV
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/03/warm-winter-destroys-germanys-eiswein-crop?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Live Footage of German Vineyards
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Grape guy fanning himself" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/78/grape_gif.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Grape guy fanning himself" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/78/grape_gif.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For the first time ever, German vintners aren't producing any Eiswein after wine-growing regions <a href="https://www.foxnews.com/world/warm-winter-ice-wine-german-harvest-ruined-climate-change?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">failed to reach</a> low enough temperatures. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Production of Eiswein, or ice wine, has fallen since the ’80s and today accounts for about 0.1% of German wine production. But as one of the country’s most famous (and expensive) wine exports, it’s an early indication of how climate change is impacting the industry. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Not your grandma’s frosé </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Eiswein production, which originated in 18th or 19th century Germany, is about as thrilling as a <em>Planet Earth</em> snake chase scene. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Vintners let grapes <a href="https://www.atlasobscura.com/foods/ice-wine-eiswein?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">concentrate and dehydrate</a> on the vine through winter. Grapes can only be harvested if temperatures drop below 18°F (so that when they're pressed, only sugar and juice concentrate is released). </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Some farmers freeze grapes artificially, but can’t legally call it “Eiswein” since Germany </span><span><a href="https://www.winespectator.com/articles/german-ice-wine-rules-tightened-49351?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tighened</a></span><span> regulations following the “ice wine fiasco of 2011.” </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For you winos, this means you’re stuck pairing spicy pad thai with a Riesling. Quelle horreur.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we’re here: </strong>Other winemakers are benefiting from warming winters. Go deeper with our breakdown of how climate change is <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/10/18/climate-change-disrupting-wine-industry?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">disrupting wine production</a>.</p>

</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If your career ceiling is low, your life can be pretty uncomfortable—particularly in the age of standing desks.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://bs.serving-sys.com/Serving/adServer.bs?cn=trd&pli=1075246408&adid=1079925521&ord=[timestamp]" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">IMA® (Institute of Management Accountants)</a> is here to help remodel your career's ceiling. As a CMA® (Certified Management Accountant), you’ll be equipped with the skills you need to thrive in the finance and accounting world.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Closer to a career ceiling of a Gothic cathedral than a one-story house, the CMA certification provides you with:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Greater credibility</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Higher earning potential</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>A pathway to leadership roles</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://bs.serving-sys.com/Serving/adServer.bs?cn=trd&pli=1075246408&adid=1079925521&ord=[timestamp]" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">CMA</a> is the global benchmark for business professionals in accounting and finance.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Raise your ceiling <a href="https://bs.serving-sys.com/Serving/adServer.bs?cn=trd&pli=1075246408&adid=1079925521&ord=[timestamp]" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">today</a>.</p>
</td>
</tr>

</tr>
</table>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/03/beige-book-matters?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Beige Book: Not as Dull as It Sounds
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="beige book " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83Ny9iZWlnZV9ib29rLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>The Federal Reserve</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s Day 3 of our weeklong series explaining the important events on the economic calendar. So far, we’ve covered the ISM Manufacturing Report and central bank meetings. Today, we turn to the <a href="https://www.frbsf.org/education/publications/doctor-econ/2003/november/monetary-policy-beige-book-interest-rates/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Beige Book</a>, which is due this afternoon.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Who publishes it: </strong>The U.S. Federal Reserve. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How often? </strong>Eight times a year.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What’s in it? </strong>Stories about economic growth from 12 districts across the U.S. These reports are localized: We may hear about port delays affecting business in Los Angeles or a shortage of pretzels wreaking havoc in Philly. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Is it important? </strong>Yes, mainly because of its timing. The report is usually released two weeks ahead of the Fed’s scheduled monetary policy meetings, so it has the potential to influence central bankers’ decisions. But since it’s more Word doc than spreadsheet, it’s been called the “ask your uncle survey” by one former Fed vice chair. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Fun fact: </strong>The Beige Book is actually the report’s <a href="https://www.thebalance.com/beige-book-definition-of-federal-reserve-report-3305816?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">nickname</a>. Its official moniker is “Summary of Commentary on Current Economic Conditions by Federal Reserve District.”</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Olympic legend Usain Bolt’s always been quick off the block, but the scooter venture he cofounded is fighting a yearslong headstart by competitors like Lime, Bird, and Skip. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">This might help:</strong> Bolt Mobility said it closed a <a href="https://www.axios.com/bolt-mobility-30-million-venture-capital-funding-32ac4100-8f11-4083-8997-051795e8ce4c.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Series A funding round</a> yesterday, bringing its total investment to $30 million. Now valued at $100 million, the Miami Beach startup operates ~5,000 scooters in cities from Fort Lauderdale to Paris.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Now here's what you've been waiting for...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Bolt scooter max speed: 30 mph</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Usain Bolt max speed: 27.8 mph at the Berlin 2009 World Championships </span></li>
</ul>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">No better time to revisit our grammar quiz than on National Grammar Day. See if you can spot the grammatical and stylistic errors in these sentences <a href="https://blogs.wsj.com/styleandsubstance/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">from the WSJ editors</a>. </p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Lincoln's prose, borne of his immersion in Shakespeare and the King James Bible, invested the Union cause with a moral majesty that sanctified a fratricidal conflict.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Wrapping around the monument’s entrance, which is bound by two small towers, are terra-cotta panels by Caspar Buberl narrating Garfield’s life, portraying him as an educator, a hero of the Civil War, an orator, taking the presidential oath, and laying in state.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In 2011, al­lies launched a bomb­ing campaign on Libya that even­tually lead to an over­throw of the gov­ern­ment and the death of strong­man Col. Moam­mar Gad­hafi.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>He lobbied in Washington for funding to build a levy that still protects the city’s riverfront.</span></li>
</ol>

<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Lincoln’s prose was “born of his immersion,” not “borne.” </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>This is a twofer: First, Garfield should be “lying in state.” Second, the monument’s entrance is “bounded by two small towers,” not “bound.” </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The campaign “led” to an overthrow.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>He lobbied for a “levee,” not a “levy.” The WSJ notes that if you’ve been humming “Drove my Chevy to the levy” for years, you’re also wrong.</span></li>
</ol>
</td>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nECONOMY\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/03/fed-cuts-interest-rates-stem-effects-coronavirus?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nExtraordinary Times Call for Monetary Policy Measures\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Jerome Powell testifying before Congress\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC84MC9qZXJvbWVfcG93ZWxsLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eU.S. Federal Reserve\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen the U.S. economy gets a mustard stain, you can always rely on the Federal Reserve for Tide to Go. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn a surprising move yesterday, the central bank \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/03/fed-cuts-rates-by-half-a-percentage-point-to-combat-coronavirus-slowdown.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecut interest rates\u003c/a\u003e by half a percentage point, the first time it’s applied Emergen-C stimulus since the 2008 financial crisis. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“The fundamentals of the U.S. economy remain strong,” a Fed statement read. \"However, the coronavirus poses evolving risks to the economy.” \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFed Chair Jerome Powell acknowledged that the rate cut won’t reduce the infection rate or repair broken supply chains, but it will “help boost household and business confidence.” \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe reaction\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMarkets: \u003c/strong\u003enot reassured. The major indexes each fell nearly 3%, wiping out any optimism from Monday’s rally. Investors loaded up on the canned beans of the finance world—government bonds—dropping the 10-year Treasury yield below 1% for the first time ever.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePresident Trump:\u003c/strong\u003e not satisfied with the amount of easing and cutting. “More easing and cutting!” he tweeted following the central bank’s announcement. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eTreasury Secretary Mnuchin: \u003c/strong\u003epicked up his cheerleader pom poms. “They did the right thing getting ahead of this...I applaud the Fed on this move.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBut this is a global problem\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd major economies \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/03/business/central-banks-coronavirus-g7.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edon’t seem united\u003c/a\u003e in their response. Before the Fed’s decision yesterday, leaders from the G7 said they were “closely monitoring the spread of the coronavirus disease,” but didn’t lay out any coordinated action. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAs we discussed yesterday, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/02/quick-debrief-central-bank-meetings?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einterest rates\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e are already at historic lows across the world, leaving central banks without First Aid kits to dress economic wounds.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe Bank of England, for example, is in no hurry to cut rates. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ein the U.S., more cuts seem imminent. The next one could happen at the Fed's regularly scheduled meeting March 17–18. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs the coronavirus spreads, companies and governments are struggling to keep opportunists from \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/03/amazon-walmart-e-retailers-battle-price-gouging-on-coronavirus-products.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eexploiting demand\u003c/a\u003e for medical supplies. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAs of yesterday, there were more than 91,300 confirmed cases and at least 3,110 deaths worldwide. In the U.S., there have been at least nine deaths and over 100 confirmed cases. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFear of contracting the virus sent prices of supplies like facemasks and hand sanitizer, especially those hawked by third-party sellers, through several roofs. Amazon said last week it had taken down over 1 million listings because of price gouging or misleading descriptions related to the coronavirus. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eBut that's not enough. The FT found a pack of 20 masks that usually goes for around $15 being \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/8db033ac-5d11-11ea-b0ab-339c2307bcd4?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eresold on the site for $387\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ea New York state senator floated a bill to step up penalties Diego\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTwo recent analyses suggest a few U.S. cities are hogging the fruits of the U.S.’ record economic expansion. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe first:\u003c/strong\u003e The WSJ reports that the proportion of U.S. cities expecting general fund revenue to slide more than 3% by the end of fiscal 2019 \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/for-growing-numbers-of-struggling-u-s-cities-the-downturn-has-arrived-11583248603?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ejumped to 27% from 17%\u003c/a\u003e (adjusting for inflation, of course). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eGeneral fund revenue = city money not yet designated for a specific purpose. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWhen cities are budget-strapped, not only do services suffer and taxes go up, but officials can’t plan long-term. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eSome U.S. cities are flush with cash provided by new, highly taxable tech workers. But a larger share still suffer from the extended bottoming out of American manufacturing. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhich brings us to \u003ca href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/research/tech-is-still-concentrating/?utm_source=newsletter\u0026utm_medium=email\u0026utm_campaign=newsletter_axioslogin\u0026stream=top\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethe second analysis\u003c/a\u003e, courtesy of The Brookings Institution. The think tank’s thinkers say tech employment growth is heavily concentrating in coastal cities like Seattle, Boston, San Francisco, and San Diego. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe top 10 metro areas with the highest shares of the U.S. digital services industry captured 47.9% of the country’s new tech jobs from 2010 to 2018.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor the first time ever, German vintners aren't producing any Eiswein after wine-growing regions \u003ca href=\"https://www.foxnews.com/world/warm-winter-ice-wine-german-harvest-ruined-climate-change?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efailed to reach\u003c/a\u003e low enough temperatures. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eProduction of Eiswein, or ice wine, has fallen since the ’80s and today accounts for about 0.1% of German wine production. But as one of the country’s most famous (and expensive) wine exports, it’s an early indication of how climate change is impacting the industry. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eNot your grandma’s frosé \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eEiswein production, which originated in 18th or 19th century Germany, is about as thrilling as a \u003cem\u003ePlanet Earth\u003c/em\u003e snake chase scene. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eVintners let grapes \u003ca href=\"https://www.atlasobscura.com/foods/ice-wine-eiswein?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003econcentrate and dehydrate\u003c/a\u003e on the vine through winter. Grapes can only be harvested if temperatures drop below 18°F (so that when they're pressed, only sugar and juice concentrate is released). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eSome farmers freeze grapes artificially, but can’t legally call it “Eiswein” since Germany \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.winespectator.com/articles/german-ice-wine-rules-tightened-49351?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etighened\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e regulations following the “ice wine fiasco of 2011.” \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor you winos, this means you’re stuck pairing spicy pad thai with a Riesling. Quelle horreur.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ While we’re here: \u003c/strong\u003eOther winemakers are benefiting from warming winters. Go deeper with our breakdown of how climate change is \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/10/18/climate-change-disrupting-wine-industry?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edisrupting wine production\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Federal Reserve\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s Day 3 of our weeklong series explaining the important events on the economic calendar. So far, we’ve covered the ISM Manufacturing Report and central bank meetings. Today, we turn to the \u003ca href=\"https://www.frbsf.org/education/publications/doctor-econ/2003/november/monetary-policy-beige-book-interest-rates/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eBeige Book\u003c/a\u003e, which is due this afternoon.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWho publishes it: \u003c/strong\u003eThe U.S. Federal Reserve. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow often? \u003c/strong\u003eEight times a year.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat’s in it? \u003c/strong\u003eStories about economic growth from 12 districts across the U.S. These reports are localized: We may hear about port delays affecting business in Los Angeles or a shortage of pretzels wreaking havoc in Philly. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIs it important? \u003c/strong\u003eYes, mainly because of its timing. The report is usually released two weeks ahead of the Fed’s scheduled monetary policy meetings, so it has the potential to influence central bankers’ decisions. But since it’s more Word doc than spreadsheet, it’s been called the “ask your uncle survey” by one former Fed vice chair. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFun fact: \u003c/strong\u003eThe Beige Book is actually the report’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.thebalance.com/beige-book-definition-of-federal-reserve-report-3305816?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enickname\u003c/a\u003e.
